Authors:
Ryo Sugawara, Kozue Sotome, Nitaro Maekawa, Akira Nakagiri,
Naoki Endo
Title: Systematic revisions of Hydnum species in Japan.
Keywords:
Cantharellales; cryptic species; East Asian species;
ectomycorrhizal fungi; ITS; mating test; tef1; 9 new taxa.
Abstract:
Hydnum (Hydnaceae, Basidiomycota) shows endemic species
diversity in East Asia; however, few comprehensive taxonomic studies
have been conducted to date. In this study, we performed morphological,
ecological, phylogenetic, and biological evaluation of the taxonomy of
Hydnum species in Japan. In total, 186 Japanese Hydnum specimens were
used for morphological observation. Phylogenetic trees were constructed
using sequence data of nuc rDNA internal transcribed spacer
ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 (ITS) region and the translation elongation factor 1-Î±
(tef1) gene. Intra- and interspecific mating tests using 78 monokaryotic
strains of 13 species did not conflict with species delimitation
inferred from their ITS and tef1 phylogenetic relationships. This study
provides detailed morphological descriptions of sixteen rigorously
identified species from Japan, nine of which are described as new
species: H. alboluteum, H. albopallidum, H. pinicola, H. itachiharitake,
H. minospororufescens, H. orientalbidum, H. subberkeleyanum, H.
tomaense, and H. tottoriense. Three species described in this work are
new to Japan: H. boreorepandum, H. mulsicolor, and H. umbilicatum. The
remaining three species previously reported from Japan, are re-described
using data from newly collected materials: H. cremeoalbum, H. minus and
H. repando-orientale. These results imply high species diversity of
Hydnum species even within this limited region of East Asia.
